summary.title: History: Theory of Computation
summary.description: The history of computers and early calculators will be examined. Students will learn the principles of early computational devices and investigate how the concepts utilized in these devices are implemented in modern computers. Particular attention is focused on Boolean logic, Frege formula language, and Turing machines. Implications of Shannon’s Law and Moore’s Law will also be studied. The course is offered in an online Internet format.

book.title: The Universal Computer: The Road from Leibniz to Turing

course-outcomes.outcome: Understand the principles of early computational devices.
Understand the significance of finite and infinite number representation.
Comprehend the basics of Turing universal computing machines.
Understand the limits of Shannon's Law and the implications of Moore's Law.

course-content.topic: Ancient computers from Babylon to Greece.
Improvements to mechanical devices: multiplication and division.
Leibniz vision of a universal computing device.
The future of computing: Shannon's Law and Moore's Law.
